content.description: Start directly behind the tree that looks like it has five trunks.  The crux of the route is at the beginning, the first ten feet or so of the climb.  After climbing the first ten feet, traverse to the diagonal hand crack about 5 feet to the left.  There is a loose block in the crack, so be careful what you grab.  Once you reach the crack, the rest of the climb is about a 5.6/5.7.  Continue straight up to the bolted anchors.
content.protection: Top rope.  There are two bolts on the top of the cliff for an anchor.
content.location: At the base of this route there is a large tree that looks like it has five trunks.  The route starts directly behind the tree.

content.description: This route features a small overhang followed by a slab section. If you don't use the ledge to the left as a foothold while going over the lip, the movement is quite interesting, and the difficulty becomes a grade harder. This route has no bolts and requires the creation of an anchor. It is pretty good practice for setting up anchors. There are trees, cracks, and drill holes to choose from.
content.location: This route is most of the way down the right side of the wall and is easy to spot by its overhanging section.

content.description: This is probably the nicest and most flow-y problem in the park. It features shouldery moves, pinches on pebbles, and a huge toe hook! Start matched on a good hold as far left as you can go, and work your way right and over the lip.
content.protection: It feels a lot better to have two pads.
content.location: This boulder is at the back corner of the park and faces the VA Medical Center. It is directly above the Bepo's Problem Boulder.

content.description: I am not sure whether this route is in any guidebooks or has been named already. Either way, it appears not to be on Mountain Project, and seeing as how it really jumps off the rock as a very obvious and fun looking traverse, I though I'd upload it here. 3 areas jump out as being particularly difficult: namely the start with bad feet and the last 10 feet or so, which are just tricky. Overall, this is an interesting and fun climb in my opinion - a straightfoward but challenging traverse for anyone first climbing on puddingstone.
content.location: Starting on an obvious, sharp jug on the far left of a long, horizontal crack about 6-7 feet high on the main face of Nira, traverse to the right ending as far right as you can go.

content.description: This is an open project on the main boulder at the back of the park. Start low on the two crimps, and go straight up the face, avoiding the arete to the right as used in Bird Tutorial. The difficulty should be in the V5-V7 range, and the climb consists of just a few powerful and insecure moves. The landing is short but very sketchy, so be careful about how you protect it, and bring a spotter!
content.location: This boulder is at the back corner of the park and faces the VA Medical Center. It is directly above the Bepo's Problem Boulder.

content.description: This climb finishes the same way as Nira but starts to the left with 10 feet of very easy climbing. It can be done on the same anchor, but you will take a swing if you fall near the bottom.
content.location: This is on the main face right by the entrance to the park when coming from Jefferson Playground or Nira Ave.

content.description: This climb goes up the center of the main, vertical face at Nira Rock. It has two bolts and can be done on lead, along with a toprope anchor above. This climb features dozens of crimps which are invisible from the ground. The challenge and fun of it is finding the path which works for you! All of the rock at Nira is puddingstone, and occasionally pebbles will break lose from the routes.
content.protection: Two bolts and an anchor at the top.
content.location: This is the main face right by the entrance to the park when coming from Jefferson Playground or Nira Ave.

content.description: Climb straight up the rock face using small feet and solid crimps on both sides. You can top out and climb another 20 feet to the very top, or climb down at the ledge.
content.location: This is the first climbable face on your left after starting down the path parallel to the VA parking lot. It is 10-15 feet to the right of the corner slab boulder.

content.description: Follow the obvious vein until you can reach the jugs to top out. Avoid the holds to the left as used in Ivy Tower. You can climb down to the left, or follow the slab to the very top (20 additional feet).
content.location: This is the first climbable face on your left after starting down the path parallel to the VA parking lot. It is 10-15 feet to the right of the corner slab boulder.

content.description: This is an alternate start to No Dogs Allowed, sharing start holds with Bird Tutorial.
content.location: This boulder is at the back corner of the park and facing the VA Medical Center. It is directly above the Bepo's problem boulder

content.description: This climb goes up the right side of the main face. It features some larger stones and big shoulder-y moves between them at the start. When you get near the top, good luck finding anything to pull on! This route can only be climbed on toprope using the same anchor as Nira. It is possible to redirect the rope by putting a cam in a solid crack above the finishing ledge if you want to work on the top sequence. This climb stays wet longer than any of the others, so you might have to wait 3-5 days after rain to try it.
content.location: This is on the main face right by the entrance to the park, coming from Jefferson Playground or Nira Ave. It runs 5-6 feet to the right of the 2 bolts and Nira.

content.description: This was not named, because it was climbed out of desperation during the COVID-19 pandemic but because there was a smashed Corona bottle on the ledge close to the top of the route. Climb the slab on the left until you can reach the jugs, then follow the jugs until you can mantel onto the ledge.
content.location: It is on the VA parking lot side of the rock.

content.description: This is a short, little, slab problem to warm up upon. You either have to downclimb the slab or downclimb the back, which may actually be a harder problem.
content.location: It is on the obvious boulder on the corner facing the VA parking lot and the Jefferson Playground.

content.description: This climb follows the arete from the base as far up as you can go, using feet primarily on the left face. The most natural finish hold is a golf ball sized pocket just over the arete near the top. When you reach it, rock over and use the good ledge to top out. This is a very physical boulder.
content.location: This is on the large boulder to the right of the main face

content.description: This problem starts in a crunched position on a pretty bad crimp and undercling. It then goes straight up using the arete. This problem requires a lot more tension than No Dogs Allowed.
content.location: This boulder is at the back corner of the park and faces the VA Medical Center. It is directly above the Bepo's Problem Boulder.

content.description: This is a low ball which can be climbed from a sit start with both hands on the undercling, followed by a couple of thin cracks. It is harder than it looks to establish!
content.protection: It is nice to have a pad.
content.location: This boulder is near the end of the path running parallel to the VA parking lot, right where the path turns left and goes up steeply.

content.description: Nira Rock Urban Wild is a old area in Boston's Jamaica Plain neighborhood. It is managed by a non-profit group called Friends of Nira Rock and is free and open to the public. It is a puddingstone face with a variety of features and textures. There are currently two bolted anchors for toprope routes and one set of bolts on the main face for sport climbing. Additional rope climbing exists but requires more creative anchors. There are a number of boulder problems documented with the potential for more. It is an urban park, so beware of broken glass in and around the rocks.
